section.name: Introduction to content add-on development
section.span: An introduction to content add-on development.
section.p: As you are developing the website, you'll need to be able to extend Hippo CMS. Perhaps you have created your own Document Type, a [FIXME] site map or some documents with test data. It is possible to capture this work in an add-on, thereby making it possible to use version control, use an automated build process, share your work with the community, etcetera.

The repository can be extended in numerous ways. Its content can be read from (multiple) XML files, new namespaces can be defined and additional workflows can be installed. We'll discuss the different types of add-on that are typically used during website development.

subsection.name: Content add-on
subsection.p: The simplest of add-ons, this type contains only a handful of files that are imported by the repository at startup. These files can contain JCR trees, in the format that is exported by the CMS console's "Export Node" action.

subsection.name: Editing Template add-on
subsection.p: Any repository add-on can also contain a namespace definition with node types. These add-ons contain the types as created with the Document Type Editor. See the tutorial on how to create a template addon for more information.

subsection.name: More
subsection.p: In a more advanced project, document types get complex and their templates may need to be customized. You can find more information about how to create a custom layout or maybe even how to create your own editing plugin in the CMS Customization section.
